title: PSA: Dont Play League of Legends as if it were Call of Duty.
body:
It isnt about kills.

It is about objectives.

Think strategy.

Not running around for kills.

In Normal, go ahead, but in RANKED DONT CHASE or get greedy.

There is a difference between greed or stupidity, and initiative.

Initiative, you see an opponent get caught out, you pounce on him/her.

Greed, you go in 1v1, get baited and turns into a 1v2 or 1v3, then you get shutdown.

Initiative, you see inhib down, you go other lanes or get drag.

Greed, you rush that lane w/ no inhib, waste time or waste baron buff.

So please, think of the bigger picture. Not about your KDA.

A bronze 5 mid who can last hit every single minion in lane then farm the jungle in between waves will then be able to beat a platinum 5 who plays jungle due to being good for all the opposite reason

if youre bronze 5 and you can last hit more than 1 minion per wave you obviously aint bronze 5. people in low plat usually get ~70-80 cs per 10 mins, people in gold 3+ 60-70, people gold 4 and below usually 30-60 cs per 10, which is 30-60% of the minions that come into the lane, or barely 3 minions per wave.

Stop saying that all bronze players suck at everything with nothing but anecdotal evidence to try and disprove a theoretical situation that was initially made to explain my point (and it's not even the main subject of discussion). A majority of them are simply good at one thing and can't do anything else.

I'm not trying to say bronze players are stupid or something like that, they're in bronze because they're trying to learn more advanced mechanics than the bare minimum. 

Like, bronze is like elementary school or something. Little kids aren't stupid because they haven't learned anything yet, but if they keep practicing they'll get better and eventually climb on out of bronze. My point was that even silver and low gold players can't even farm, it's a very advanced skill (even though it sounds SO easy in theory) so that would be a pretttty far fetched theoretical scenario, maybe like saying there's a bronze player who can mechanically perfectly play lee sin better than someone in skt.

If an elementary school child knew how to run a nuclear power plant but couldn't manage money, weren't emotionally developed enough to resist making an intentional literal meltdown upon being antagonized, and didn't know what to do when a stranger asks for a sample of uranium without any license, then that child still belongs in an elementary school. If all elementary children suddenly gained the ability to do math and english at a university level, then they'd beat the primary school children who are good at those subjects, but fail to compete with students in other subjects like music or history. These examples are blowing things out of proportion, but it's to make clear what would happen in a less exaggerated situation.

Also, farming is the easiest skill in LoL, past basic controls. It's easier than warding, harassing, and even pushing without CS in mind (shoving requires mana management to be able to do anything afterwards.)

Ironically, Call of Duty favors objectives more than kills relative to League of Legends.

In Call of Duty, the objectives are the win conditions, in League of Legends most of them are only means towards win conditions
In Call of Duty, you pursue kills to reduce the enemy team's numbers and give your team a power play at objectives, in League of Legends you pursue kills for the same reasons IN ADDITION TO kill gold for your team to make your champions stronger.
Call of duty's most played game modes are death match with no objectives. Meanwhile League has absolutely no death match modes

That's not really a fair comparison of the high-end of the game. You can't use Ranked League and compare it to TDM or FFA because that's intentionally taking something popular on one game and comparing it to the competitive part of another game. That's like comparing a Street Fighter tourney to For Glory mode on Smash 4 - it's popular and has a semi-competitive feel, but popularity does not beget the actual competitive aspect. 

It'd probably be a lot more fair to use the actual competitive aspects of a game to compare it to the actual competitive aspects of another game. Something like Hardpoint, Domination, Capture the Flag, etc., as compared to TDM/FFA in CoD, or Normals or ARAM in League.
